narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Ranran Wang  Ranran. She's the BEST!
Instructor: Ranran Wang  Ranran Wang
Instructor: Ranran Wang  Ranran Wang
Instructor: Ranran Wang  Ranran
Instructor: Ranran Wang  Ranran Wang

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Ranran Wang  She is the best in every way! A rockstar!!!!!!
Instructor: Ranran Wang  Excellent TA. Very helpful and always made the time to explain anything you asked.

Instructor: Ranran Wang  Ranran was wonderfully organized, was willing to meet outside of the classroom to explain difficult topics, and could explain them in a way that was different and complementary to Edgar's explanations (which was useful when a topic wasn't fully understood in class).

Instructor: Ranran Wang  The teaching assistant was very accessible and took active interest in the progress of the students.She also engaged students during the class discussions.She was also very lucid in her explanation.

Instructor: Ranran Wang  Ranran was helpful and responsive for all of our questions. It may be helpful to hold regular TA office hours for students to ask questions regarding problem sets or other course work. I wasn't clear on whether this was available to us this year, so it may've been just a matter of communication.

Instructor: Ranran Wang  Ranran was really helpful in making herself available to student questions and concerns. I thought that her review session for the midterm was great and helped assuage many of my concerns and make my study process a lot more streamlined. Ranran replied to all of my emails promptly when I had questions about the problem sets.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: This class was amazing on multiple levels. I have two suggestions. First, the problem sets seemed like busy work and seemed disconnected from the material. Also they were graded freakishly harshly. Second, the course seemed to sag in the middle. I don't know if it's because you missed two classes. But it sort of lost focus and cohesion for a while. So maybe you could try to keep the same level of commitment and intensity next time you teach the course.
I really appreciated the mid-semester check-in/survey that Edgar had us complete, which allowed us to tell him what we thought was working or could be improved with the class.

Question 1: I thought the readings offered a very broad view of the literature and were not too long. Question 2: The problem sets were not too long and helped solidify our understanding of the calculations behind the aspects we were learning in the readings. Question 11: Professor Hertwich was very friendly and a joy to have leading the class. He made sure we were all learning the material and understanding the things he was explaining.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Readings and discussion.

The fact that you challenged us to think big about climate mitigation in the broadest sense and encouraged discussion about complex almost philosophical issues associated with climate change mitigation.
The in-class open discussions.
All of the course materials and readings complimented by Edgar's insights and commentary were invaluable.

I think this class provides an excellent overview of climate change mitigation efforts and what is feasible from an industrial ecology standpoint. I thought that the readings were a very strong aspect of the course.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Discussion can be improved. The course should have a strict no technology policy.

The graded bits. The problem sets seemed like busy work and didn't reinforce learning. Also they were graded freakishly harshly (even worse than ESA which I thought set the bar for that). And the midterm seemed similarly disconnected. The final (a 48 hour timed essay) was alright. But overall maybe you could figure out an improved way to give us work and evaluate that work.

Better structure to prepare for class: I'd suggest to have students send in questions about the literature in advance instead of doing "quizzes" to make sure we read the material, that's more something for undergrads. Making students come up with their key questions also ensures that they have read the material, and is the best starting point for a fruitful discussion.

I think the final exam assignment could've been interesting as a semester-long project. Overall, I wanted more time to think through and assimilate the breadth of course material into a more meaningful response. It even could've been helpful to receive the prompts a week or a few days prior to the 48-hr exam time window, as there were many other resources that I would've liked to draw from in my response. Anything that could've helped us to be better prepared would've been welcome.

After three straight hours, the lectures seemed to drag on a bit. I think that there could be more discussion among the students to splice up the lectures. I also think that Edgar could work on the pacing of his lectures a bit more so that the lectures weren't going over the course period.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This challenged my professional thinking about climate mitigation because it cited it within an academic context of understanding climate mitigation. Which was rad! This is what grad school is supposed to be all about.

The class gave a great overview of all the different aspects/areas related to climate change and mitigation but at the same time also really did dive deeper into the material so we did get some in-depth knowledge about the different parts. It was in that sense very useful if you care about climate change and impacts on the future, and I think because it relates to so much it is important for everyone in this field to understand (whether it is forestry or material science or energy, etc.).

This course is great as an introductory course to IE; it probably should not be taken by anyone with any significant IE background. As I did not have this background, it was a marvelous survey course for me!

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Interest in climate change mitigation.
I wanted to learn about climate mitigation.

Because I am interested in industrial ecology thinking but my study focus is more on climate/energy/sustainable development, so this course kind of combined the substance with the methods/approach which was very cool, interesting, and useful.

This course was one of the few climate change courses offered at FES (ironically?); additionally, one of the few mitigation courses offered; and it was appropriate for someone who had no IE background.
I was shopping classes and was interested in industrial ecology so this seemed like a great addition to my schedule.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: This challenged my professional thinking about climate mitigation because it cited it within an academic context of understanding climate mitigation. Which was rad! This is what grad school is supposed to be all about.
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Working in groups was very helpful for all of the problem sets. I appreciated the opportunity to learn from other students, especially because I think we were a diverse group and each of us had varying strengths.

We had one problem set that was group work. It was fine, except that it was right before spring break so we didn't have much time to reconvene to finish the things we weren't able to finish during the class period.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Do the readings before going to the class.

This class is the bee's knees! You go through climate mitigation sector by sector and talk about it from an industrial ecology perspective. You're not going to hear trite un-informed truisms about climate mitigation ("solar is grrrreat!!!") that you hear in other (ahem) energy policy classes at FES. You're going to do a review of the scientific literature of climate mitigation in each sector of the economy. And you're going to talk about it. And you're going to learn some stuff. And ultimately you're going to be freaked out because it ain't pretty (there are no easy answers). Cool class. Also Edgar is super nice.

Prepare well for the discussions by reading the articles as otherwise you won't get much out of that and will be wasting time. Make sure to ask the professor very particular questions, perhaps in advance, so he can address that during his presentations.
Great course!
I recommend this course if you are looking for a good introduction to climate change mitigation efforts and looking to get a better understanding of the IPCC and its goals.
